text: Introduction to Probability Lecture 2 Today Combinatorics Uniform Probability Attendance: 35045358 Introduction to Probability Summary (last time) Probability has three components 1. The sample space Ω 2. The events which are subsets of Ω 3. The probability function 𝑃(𝑥) which assigns probability to every event in Ω The probability is normalised P Ω = 1 Introduction to Probability Combinatorics and Counting Combinatorics We count the number of ways of something happening. Example: We toss two dice. How many ways are there of getting a given total? One way to get 2: (1,1) Three ways to get a 4: (3,1), (2,2) and (3,1) Example: How many Sudoku boards are there? (≈ 6.7 × 1021) Introduction to Probability Nomenclature We will use Ω to represent the set of possible outcomes. We will use |Ω| to represent the number of outcomes. Example Toss one die: Ω = {1,2,3,4,5,6} Ω = 6 Introduction to Probability Sampling An important aspect (here) of combinatorics is sampling. Sampling involves 𝑁 objects and picking 𝑘 of them. For example: pick a 4-number password (a PIN). We can 1. Sample with replacement and keep order. Pick the 4 numbers freely. 2. Sample without replacement and keep order. Ensure that no numbers are repeated. 3. Sample without replacement and ignore order. The bottom door of Physics East! 4. Sample with replacement and ignore order. How many different sequences are there? Introduction to Probability Ω = 10! 7! = 720 Permutations Sample 𝑁 things from 𝑁 objects without replacement: i.e. we draw them all. We get Ω = 𝑁 × 𝑁 − 1 × ⋯ × 2 × 1 = 𝑁! The number of ways of permuting 𝑁 objects. Typically, 𝑁! 𝑁−𝑘 ! is called a 𝑘-permutation of 𝑁. Sample 𝑘 things from 𝑁 objects without replacing, and ignoring the order they appeared. We get 𝑁! (𝑁−𝑘)! for the possible draws, but this overcounts.
